page.title: 05FORESTRY - DERWENT VALLEY
page.content: Chopwell Woodlands has been looked after, on a leasehold basis, by the Forestry Commission since its formation in 1919.It once belonged to monks, who leased it to farmers and in turn was leased to noblemen and clergy, but because of their importance, the woodlands were eventually kept by the Crown. Coalming has left the land with many problems involving subsidence. Since nationalisation in 1947 records show that drift mines broke surface in at least two places in the woodlands. Today felling of trees continues. Two forestry workers are responsible for the organisation throughout the wood- lands of the North East. Great care is taken not to disturb the balance of nature and natural habitat of much of the wildlife when felling takes place.
